DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term representing a diagnostic criterion of Cowden Syndrome, a hereditary disease characterized by multiple ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal nevoid and neoplastic anomalies, papules of the face and oral mucosa, and other changes occur in the skin, in the thyroid, the breast, the gastrointestinal system, and the nervous system.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A hereditary disease characterized by multiple ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal nevoid and neoplastic anomalies. Papules of the face and oral mucosa are the most characteristic lesion. Other changes occur in the skin, in the thyroid, the breast, the gastrointestinal system, and the nervous system._The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A hereditary disease characterized by multiple ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal nevoid and neoplastic anomalies. Papules of the face and oral mucosa are the most characteristic lesion. Other changes occur in the skin, in the thyroid, the breast, the gastrointestinal system, and the nervous system.

Concepts.definition: An autosomal dominant hereditary syndrome characterized by a variety of hamartomas and neoplasms including verrucous skin lesions, fibromas of the oral cavity, facial trichilemmomas, hamartomatous colonic polyps, thyroid neoplasms, breast cancer, and dysplastic gangliocytomas of the cerebellum.

Property.preferredDefinition: The process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms.

Concepts.definition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A hereditary disease characterized by multiple ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal nevoid and neoplastic anomalies. Papules of the face and oral mucosa are the most characteristic lesion. Other changes occur in the skin, in the thyroid, the breast, the gastrointestinal system, and the nervous system._Characteristic or indicative of (e.g., a disease)._That which constitutes a standard from which a judgment can be established, a reference point against which other things can be evaluated, or a basis for comparison._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

PermissibleValues.value: GU tumours (eg, renal cell carcinoma, uterine fibroids) or malformation
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: GU tumours (eg, renal cell carcinoma, uterine fibroids) or malformation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: GU tumours (eg, renal cell carcinoma, uterine fibroids) or malformation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: GU tumours (eg, renal cell carcinoma, uterine fibroids) or malformation
A benign tumor of fibrous or fully developed connective tissue.

Concepts.definition: A non-metastasizing neoplasm arising from the fibrous tissue. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign, usually painless, well-circumscribed lipomatous tumor composed of adipose tissue.

Concepts.definition: A benign, usually painless, well-circumscribed lipomatous tumor composed of adipose tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic disorder comprising three variants which range from lesions consisting primarily of an overgrowth of fibrous tissue to those characterized by dominance of the proliferation of the epithelial parenchyma to a form of dysplasia characterized by both stromal and epithelial hyperplasia with the formation of cysts.

Concepts.definition: Fibrosis associated with cyst formation in the breast parenchyma.

PermissibleValues.value: Other thyroid lesions (eg, adenoma or multinodular goitre)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Other thyroid lesions (eg, adenoma or multinodular goitre)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Other thyroid lesions (eg, adenoma or multinodular goitre)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Other thyroid lesions (eg, adenoma or multinodular goitre)

A malignant tumor arising from the epithelium that lines the cavity of the uterine body.  The vast majority of endometrial carcinomas are adenocarcinomas; squamous cell and adenosquamous carcinomas represent a minority of the cases.  Endometrioid adenocarcinoma is the most frequently seen variant of endometrial adenocarcinoma.  Uterine bleeding is an initial clinical sign.  The prognosis depends on the stage of the tumor, the depth of myometrial wall invasion, and the degree of differentiation. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A malignant tumor arising from the epithelium that lines the cavity of the uterine body.  The vast majority of endometrial carcinomas are adenocarcinomas; squamous cell and adenosquamous carcinomas represent a minority of the cases.  Endometrioid adenocarcinoma is the most frequently seen variant of endometrial adenocarcinoma.  Uterine bleeding is an initial clinical sign.  The prognosis depends on the stage of the tumor, the depth of myometrial wall invasion, and the degree of differentiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Dysplastic Gangliocytoma of the Cerebellum (WHO grade I), also called Lhermitte-Duclos disease, is a benign cerebellar mass, which occurs in young adults and is composed of dysplastic ganglion cells.  It is the major CNS manifestation of Cowden Disease, an autosomal dominant condition that causes a variety of hamartomas and neoplasms.(Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A benign, WHO grade I cerebellar mass, which occurs in young adults and is composed of dysplastic ganglion cells.  It is the major CNS manifestation of Cowden disease, an autosomal dominant condition that causes a variety of hamartomas and neoplasms.

PermissibleValues.value: Thyroid carcinoma, especially follicular thyroid carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the thyroid gland.  It is usually an adenocarcinoma and includes the following main subtypes: follicular, papillary, medullary, poorly differentiated, and anaplastic. --2003

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the thyroid gland. It includes the following main subtypes: follicular, papillary, medullary, poorly differentiated, and anaplastic carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
